content.text: Define acceleration
The car starts from rest
From time \(= 0\) to time \(= 15\mathrm{s}\), the car has a constant acceleration to a speed of \(28\mathrm{m / s}\)
From time \(= 15\mathrm{s}\) to time \(= 32\mathrm{s}\), the car has a constant speed of \(28\mathrm{m / s}\)
From time \(= 32\mathrm{s}\), the car has a constant deceleration of \(2.0\mathrm{m / s}^2\) until it comes to rest
On Fig. 1.1, draw the graph, using the space below for any calculations
From time \(= 15\mathrm{s}\) to time \(= 32\mathrm{s}\), the path of the car is part of a circle
For this motion, state
1. the direction of the resultant force on the car,
2. what happens to the velocity of the car
Fig. 1.1 shows the speed-time axes for the graph of the motion of a car
A force is used to move an object from the Earth's surface to a greater height
Explain why the gravitational potential energy (g.p.e.) of the object increases
Fig. 2.1 shows a train moving up towards the top of a mountain
The train transports 80 passengers, each of average mass \(65\mathrm{kg}\), through a vertical height of \(1600\mathrm{m}\)
Calculate the increase in the total gravitational potential energy (g.p.e.) of the passengers
The engine of the train has a power of \(1500\mathrm{kW}\). The time taken to reach the top of the mountain is 30 minutes
Calculate the efficiency of the engine in raising the 80 passengers \(1600\mathrm{m}\) to the top of the mountain
efficiency =   .........

The moment of a force about a pivot is equal to
State the name given to the point at which the weight of the rod acts
Calculate the mass of the rod
The rod is in equilibrium
Using data from Fig. 3.1, explain why

Fig. 3.1 shows a horizontal rod of length \(2.4 \text{m}\) and weight \(160 \text{N}\). The weight of the rod acts at its centre. The rod is suspended by two vertical ropes X and Y. The tension in each rope is \(80 \text{N}\)
Describe, in terms of molecules, why the temperature of the whole of the spoon increases
The plastic spoon is replaced by a metal spoon
Describe an additional process by which the temperature of the whole of this spoon increases

The cup contains \(150\mathrm{g}\) of liquid of specific heat capacity \(4.2\mathrm{J} / (\mathrm{g}^{\circ}\mathrm{C})\). When the cold spoon is placed into the hot liquid, the temperature of the liquid decreases from \(80^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(56^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Calculate the loss of thermal energy from the liquid
energy loss =   .........
Fig. 4.1 shows a cold plastic spoon that has just been placed in hot liquid in a cup
The motion of a single smoke particle is observed through the microscope
In the circle shown, sketch the path of this smoke particle
Explain why the smoke particle follows the path that is observed
Fig. 5.1 shows the apparatus used to observe the motion of smoke particles that are in the air in a box
Light from a lamp enters the box through a window in one side of the box. The smoke particles are observed using a microscope fixed above a window in the top of the box
A tennis player is practising by hitting a ball many times against a wall
The ball hits the wall 20 times in 60 s. The average change in momentum for each collision with the wall is \(4.2 \text{kg m / s}\)
Calculate the average force that the ball exerts on the wall
average force =   .........
Fig. 6.1 represents the electromagnetic spectrum
State the radiation in each of the regions represented by A, B, C and D in Fig. 6.1
A
B
C
D
Calculate the angle of refraction in the glass at S
angle of refraction =   .........
On Fig. 6.2, draw the refracted ray at face XY and the ray emerging from face XZ of the prism. Label this ray R.
A ray of blue light follows the same path as the ray of red light incident on the face XY
On Fig. 6.2, draw the path of this ray in the prism and emerging from the prism
Label this ray B
A source emits visible light
Fig. 6.2 shows a ray of red light from the source incident on the face XY of a glass prism at point S
The angle of incidence \(i\) of the ray is \(35^{\circ}\). The refractive index of the glass for red light is 1.5
The speed of a light wave in air is \(3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\). The refractive index of water is 1.33
Calculate the speed of the light wave in water
On Fig. 7.1,
draw the positions of the four refracted wavefronts in the plastic,
draw an arrow to show the direction of travel of the refracted wave,
label the angle of refraction \(r\) of the light wave
Fig. 7.1 shows parallel wavefronts of a light wave in air incident on a boundary with a transparent plastic
The lamp of a car headlight is rated at \(12\mathrm{V},50\mathrm{W}\)
Calculate the current in the lamp when operating normally
current =   .........
Calculate the electrical energy transferred
The fuel used by the car provides \(3.6 \times 10^{4} \text{J} /\text{cm}^{3}\)
Calculate the volume of fuel used to provide the energy calculated in **(b)**(i)
A car is driven at night
In a journey, the total charge that passes through the \(12\mathrm{V}\) battery is \(270\mathrm{kC}\)
The potential difference (p.d.) applied to the resistor is increased. Tick the box that indicates the effect on the resistance of the resistor
The potential difference (p.d.) applied to the lamp is increased. Tick the box that indicates the effect on the resistance of the lamp
The p.d. across the lamp is 6.0 V. Calculate the resistance of the lamp
resistance =   .........
The lamp and the resistor are connected in parallel to a 6.0 V supply
Calculate the current from the supply
current =   .........
The lamp and the resistor are connected in **series** to another power supply. The current in the circuit is 4.0A
Calculate the total p.d. across the lamp and the resistor
Fig. 9.1 shows current-potential difference graphs for a resistor and for a lamp
Fig. 10.1 shows a straight wire AB placed in the magnetic field between the poles of a magnet. The ends of AB are connected to a galvanometer
When AB is moved vertically, the needle of the galvanometer shows a deflection
State **three** factors that affect the size of the deflection
The primary coil P has 8000 turns and an input of 240 V. The secondary coil S has an output of 12 V
Calculate the number of turns in the secondary coil

A direct current (d.c.) is required in this resistor
On Fig. 10.2, draw this circuit

content.text: an americium nucleus \(\left(^{241}_{95}\mathrm{Am}\right)\) decays into a neptunium nucleus \(\left(^{237}_{93}\mathrm{Np}\right)\),
a phosphorus nucleus \(\left(^{32}_{15}\mathrm{P}\right)\) decays into a silicon nucleus \(\left(^{32}_{16}\mathrm{Si}\right)\)
State the type of radiation emitted when
